posts.text_en:
A pretty cool blog post came out, one I myself wanted to try writing. But I might be kinda meh as a coder and researcher. Still, on the level of vibes it‚Äôs a direct hit.

In short: in the race to automate coding and, as many believe, then the whole of software engineering after it, there‚Äôs one detail. Today everyone is trying to brute-force improve the models, and yeah, that‚Äôs understandable. Some hypothesis of the last three years: like, model performance alone is enough and then everything will be awesome. But there‚Äôs always another problem sitting right next to it.

Let‚Äôs call it the ‚Äúharness‚Äù problem. Everyone‚Äôs building the fastest car. But where you‚Äôre supposed to sit comfortably ‚Äî nobody‚Äôs thinking about that yet. Like, in code editing, just changing the approach to how we edit code and how we feed formatting into the model already changes the result a lot. In the article the guy put hashes next to line numbers and some models improved their benchmark results by 10x.

Worth noting that there are benches from JetBrains on this topic too.

And the jump in quality is insanely strong even for top models if you just change the basic format of interaction with code. AI isn‚Äôt only models, it‚Äôs tooling, it‚Äôs inference, it‚Äôs hardware ‚Äî all together. And you can run everywhere or somewhere separately. Massive field for startups.

By Seedance 2.0 and Kayne East  
So, how do you like the quality of the generated video?

‚Äú
Blue Rose Research
builds data and AI tools that help Democrats win elections‚Äù

For the weekend:

showed
how they use world models. This is just sick. They simulate road situations.
2/ it seems to me that an entrepreneur who systematically sells their time is making a mistake by not investing that time into their business (does that mean their projects are bullshit?). Because you can‚Äôt scale your own time by selling hours. But you can scale a business.

posts.text_en:
In short, once we posted the vacancy, all kinds of resumes started flying in. Since it was on LinkedIn and a bunch of other places too, I noticed one ‚Äúnuance‚Äù.

We‚Äôve got some very narrow and rare requirements in the description, like GPU kernel optimization and even better on some hypothetical Metal. You almost never see that, and in general it‚Äôs barely needed anywhere. And magically, in some resumes the experience looks roughly like:

‚Ä¢ wrote backend for a hospital or cleaned a dataset  
‚Ä¢ and then right there in January 2026 a personal project: ‚ÄúDeveloped custom  
GPU kernels in Metal  
for accelerated matrix operations, specifically targeting Apple Silicon (M1/M2/M3) for on-device LLM inference.‚Äù

Yeah sure.

üôÇ

Does someone seriously think that‚Äôs gonna affect the process in a good way. It‚Äôs a horror show, this whole ‚Äúoptimize your resume for the vacancy‚Äù thing.

Even better vibes-coding will be possible, turns out. New release from  
Anthropic ‚Äî Opus 4.6  
And right away  
a new Codex  
‚Äî brutal competition going on

Meanwhile, Google launched a pretty fun benchmark. They‚Äôre using the Kaggle platform.  
The bench is made to compare how different nets play games. Kinda interesting to look at the results. Like, who‚Äôs good at what.  
Would be cool, of course, to add real online games there and see how the nets play Dota or something like that.  
https://www.kaggle.com/game-arena

Anthropic dropped 4 insanely cool ads on the Superbowl. Monument to the agency please, that made this.
Sammy got butthurt and fired back on Twitter.
Ads are here
 (three more on their channel ‚Äî recommend all of them)
For anyone interested in what they‚Äôre looking for at YC in the new Spring 2026 batch.

There are a lot of business dudes who apparently missed the whole point of consumer products like 10 years ago and got hooked on trafflo. So here are a few important details:

‚Ä¢ AI will mass-produce the kind of hacky ‚Äúproducts‚Äù that, in the creators‚Äô heads, are supposedly needed by someone, which will make the value of an actual product idea even higher. Roughly speaking, making something that someone actually needs will get harder. That‚Äôs basically the base.

‚Ä¢ Next, the crowd is yelling like ads will run the show and the main thing is to know marketing. Well yeah, your marketing in the form of UA is obviously important. But it‚Äôs a multiplier on the base. Doesn‚Äôt matter how good you are if you‚Äôre multiplying zero. In other words, the product still has to retain and do its job.

‚Ä¢ AI, like I said, replaces a lot of stuff where you used to need pretty mediocre skills. For a good product, by itself, it‚Äôs not enough yet.

‚Ä¢ All the trafflo geniuses, with faster validation of trash hypotheses, will go en masse to pour traffic. Remember hypercasual games: made it fast and kinda poured. Now it‚Äôll be like that with products that are more complex by nature. Competition will go up, traffic prices will skyrocket, and like with the hypercasual model, the whole thing will die.

I recommend:
Andrew Chen on marketing
First Steps in Product by Scott Belsky
(one article is free, I think)

There‚Äôs another thing I‚Äôve noticed over a long time, and sometimes I catch myself doing the same too. No matter how I ask a startup founder or someone running their own project ‚Äî everyone‚Äôs doing fucking amazing. Every release is a success. It‚Äôs always like, 1-2-3-5-10-100 ARR is just around the corner, like, tomorrow, and next month there‚Äôll be a round, two, three.

I‚Äôm curious what kind of effect this creates at scale? Because 90% won‚Äôt have rounds and won‚Äôt, and will basically never have progress. Why does nobody want to share the real questions? Seems to me one of the main reasons is founder ego being pushed into the public stream. What do you think?

–¢–∞–º –î–∞—Ä–∏–æ –∑–∞–ø—É—Å—Ç–∏–ª —ç—Å—Å–µ, –∏ –≤ —ç—Ç–æ—Ç —Ä–∞–∑ –æ–Ω —Å—Ç–æ–ø–∏—Ü–æ—Ç —Ä–∞–∑ —É–∂–µ –ø–æ–≤—Ç–æ—Ä–∏–ª —á—Ç–æ –º–æ–ª –º–æ–∂–µ—Ç –æ—à–∏–±–∞—Ç—å—Å—è, —á—Ç–æ –º–æ–ª —ç—Ç–æ –≤—Å–µ–≥–æ –ª–∏—à—å –ø—Ä–¥–µ–ø–æ–ª–æ–∂–µ–Ω–∏–µ –∏ –≤—Å–µ —Ç–∞–∫–æ–µ (–∞ —á–µ –Ω–∞ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–≤—å—é —Ç–∞–∫ –Ω–µ –≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä–∏—Ç?). –ù–æ —ç—Ç–æ—Ç –µ–≥–æ —Å–∫–µ–ø—Å–∏—Å –ø–æ—Å—Ç–µ–ø–µ–Ω–Ω–æ –≤ —Ç–µ—á–µ–Ω–∏–µ —ç—Å—Å–µ –∑–∞–∫–∞–Ω—á–∏–≤–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –∏ –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –≤ –ø—Ä–∏–Ω—Ü–∏–ø–µ —Å–æ–≤–µ—Ç—É—é –ø—Ä–æ—á–µ—Å—Ç—å. –ù–æ —Å–∞–º—ã–π –≤–∞–∂–Ω—ã–π –ø—Ä—ã–∂–æ–∫ –≤ –µ–≥–æ —Ä–∞—Å—Å—É–∂–¥–µ–Ω–∏—è—Ö —Å—Ç–æ–∏—Ç –≤ —ç—Ç–æ–º –∞–±–∑–∞—Ü–µ:
We are now at the point where AI models are beginning to make progress in solving unsolved mathematical problems, and are good enough at coding that some of the strongest engineers I‚Äôve ever met are now handing over almost all their coding to AI. Three years ago, AI 
struggled with elementary school arithmetic problems
 and was barely capable of writing a single line of code. Similar rates of improvement are occurring across 
biological science
, finance, physics, and a variety of agentic tasks. If the exponential continues‚Äîwhich is not certain, but now has a decade-long track record supporting it‚Äîthen it cannot possibly be more than a few years before AI is better than humans at essentially everything.
–ì–¥–µ —Ç–∞–∫ –ø–æ –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–æ–º—É, –º–æ–ª —Ä–∞–Ω—å—à–µ –±—ã–ª–æ —Å–ª–æ–∂–Ω–æ –Ω–∞–ø–∏—Å–∞—Ç—å —Å—Ç—Ä–æ—á–∫—É –∫–æ–¥–∞, –∞ —Ç–µ–ø–µ—Ä—å –º–æ–ª –≤–æ–Ω –ª—É—á—à–µ —Ç–æ–ø –∏–Ω–∂–µ–Ω–µ—Ä–æ–≤ (—Ö–º, —ç—Ç–æ –≤—ã–≤–æ–¥ –∏–∑ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–Ω–æ –∫–∞–∫–æ–≥–æ —Ñ–∞–∫—Ç–∞? —á—Ç–æ —É –Ω–µ–≥–æ –≤ –∫–æ–º–ø–∞–Ω–∏–∏ —É—Ç–≤–µ—Ä–∂–¥–∞—é—Ç —á—Ç–æ 90% –∫–æ–¥–∞ –ø–∏—à–µ—Ç AI?). –ò –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –æ–Ω –≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä–∏—Ç, —á—Ç–æ —Ç–∞–∫ –±—É–¥–µ—Ç –≤–µ–∑–¥–µ. –°–º–µ–ª–æ. –ò —á—Ç–æ –µ—Å—Ç—å 10 –ª–µ—Ç —ç–∫—Å–ø–æ–Ω–µ–Ω—Ç—ã –∏ –æ–Ω–∞ –ø—Ä–æ–¥–æ–ª–∂–∏—Ç—Å—è (—Ç–æ–∂–µ –∑–∞–Ω—è—Ç–Ω–∞—è —ç–∫—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–ø–æ–ª—è—Ü–∏—è).  –ù–∞–ø–æ–º–∏–Ω–∞–µ—Ç –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–µ—Å—Å –≤ –∫–æ–º—å—é—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω–æ–π –≥—Ä–∞—Ñ–∏–∫–µ, –º–æ–ª —Ç—Ä–∏ –≥–æ–¥–∞ –Ω–∞–∑–∞–¥ –±—ã–ª–æ –æ–π –∫–∞–∫ –ø–ª–æ—Ö–æ, –∞ —Å–µ–π—á–∞—Å –º–æ–ª —Å–º–æ—Ç—Ä–∏—Ç–µ –º–∞—à–∏–Ω–∫–∏ –ø–æ—Ö–æ–∂–∏–µ –Ω–∞ —Ç–µ, —á—Ç–æ –Ω–∞ —É–ª–∏—Ü–µ. –°–∞–º–∏ –∑–Ω–∞–µ—Ç–µ, —á—Ç–æ –ø–æ—Ç–æ–º –∫–∞–∫-—Ç–æ —Å–∫–æ—Ä–æ—Å—Ç—å –ø–æ–¥—É–ø–∞–ª–∞, –∞ –∏ –≤—Å–µ–º –ø–ª—é—Å –º–∏–Ω—É—Å –ø–æ—Ñ–∏–≥—É —Å—Ç–∞–ª–æ.
–î–∞–ª—å—à–µ –≤—Å–µ 5 –ø—É–Ω–∫—Ç–æ–≤ —Å–æ–≤–µ—Ç—É—é –ø—Ä–æ—á–µ—Å—Ç—å. –ù–æ –µ—Å–ª–∏ –≥—Ä—É–±–æ —Ç–æ –æ–Ω –∏–¥–µ—Ç –æ—Ç —Ä–∏—Å–∫–∞ —Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—ã –≥–µ–Ω–∏–µ–≤, –ø–æ—Ç–æ–º —á—Ç–æ –º–æ–ª –Ω–∞–¥–æ —Ö–æ—Ä–æ—à–∏–µ –æ–≥—Ä–∞–Ω–∏—á–µ–Ω–∏—è –¥–µ–ª–∞—Ç—å, –ø–æ—Ç–æ–º –º–æ–ª –ø–æ–ª–∏—Ç–∏–∫–∏ —Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω –±—É–¥—É—Ç —Å–≤–æ–∏—Ö –∂–∏—Ç–µ–ª–µ–π —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ –∞–∏ —É–Ω–∏–∂–∞—Ç—å –∏ –≤–æ—Ç —Ñ–∏–≥ –ø–æ–±–µ–¥–∏—à—å (–≤–∏–¥–∏–º–æ –Ω–∞–¥–æ –±—É–¥–µ—Ç –ø–æ—Ç–æ–º –∑–∞ –¥–µ–º–æ–∫—Ä–∞—Ç–∏—é –±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç—å—Å—è —Å—Ç–∞—Ä—ã–º–∏ –º–µ—Ç–æ–¥–∞–º–∏). –ü–æ—Ç–æ–º —ç–∫–æ–Ω–æ–º–∏–∫–∞ –∏ –Ω–∞—É–∫–∞, —á—Ç–æ —Å —ç–∫–æ–Ω–æ–º–∏–∫–æ–π –≤ –ø—Ä–∏–Ω—Ü–∏–ø–µ –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ –ø–æ–Ω—è—Ç—å, –Ω–æ —Å –Ω–∞—É–∫–æ–π –º–Ω–µ –∫–∞–∂–µ—Ç—Å—è –ø–æ–∫–∞ –Ω–æ–≤—ã—Ö –∏–¥–µ–π –Ω–∞—É—á–Ω—ã—Ö –æ—Ç AI –º—ã –¥–æ–ª–≥–æ –≤–∏–¥–µ—Ç—å –Ω–µ –±—É–¥–µ–º.
–ü–æ—á–∏—Ç–∞—Ç—å —ç—Å—Å–µ —Å–∞–º–æ–º—É
posts.text_en:
So Dario dropped an essay, and this time he repeated like a hundred-fucking-times that he might be wrong, that it‚Äôs ‚Äújust a hypothesis‚Äù and all that (why doesn‚Äôt he say that in interviews though?). But this skepticism of his gradually runs out over the course of the essay, and after that I generally recommend reading on. But the most important leap in his reasoning sits in this paragraph:

We are now at the point where AI models are beginning to make progress in solving unsolved mathematical problems, and are good enough at coding that some of the strongest engineers I‚Äôve ever met are now handing over almost all their coding to AI. Three years ago, AI 
struggled with elementary school arithmetic problems
 and was barely capable of writing a single line of code. Similar rates of improvement are occurring across 
biological science
, finance, physics, and a variety of agentic tasks. If the exponential continues‚Äîwhich is not certain, but now has a decade-long track record supporting it‚Äîthen it cannot possibly be more than a few years before AI is better than humans at essentially everything.

Where it‚Äôs all so simple, like, before it was hard to write a line of code, and now look, it‚Äôs better than top engineers (hmm, that conclusion is based on what interesting fact exactly? that at his company they claim 90% of the code is written by AI?). And then he says it‚Äôll be like that everywhere. Bold. And that there are 10 years of exponential and it‚Äôll keep going (also a curious extrapolation). Reminds me of progress in computer graphics: like three years ago it was ‚Äúoh wow so bad,‚Äù and now ‚Äúlook, cars that look like the ones on the street.‚Äù You know yourselves what happened next: the pace kind of slowed down, and everyone more or less stopped giving a shit.

Further on, I recommend reading all 5 points. But roughly speaking he goes from the risk of a country of geniuses, then that we need to make good restrictions, then that politicians of countries will humiliate their residents via AI and you won‚Äôt beat that for shit (apparently then we‚Äôll have to fight for democracy using the old methods). Then economics and science: with economics you can kinda get it, but with science it seems to me we won‚Äôt be seeing new scientific ideas from AI for a long time yet.

Read the essay yourself

There‚Äôs this common take that AI will just make every link in the tech industry chain faster and more efficient. Like, now we‚Äôll hand products Claude code, we‚Äôll train them, and boom ‚Äî era of fast iterations. But I think a bit differently. My logic is roughly this (critique welcome):

- the bottleneck in any economic production process (software) is always time ‚Äî basically, how long it takes to do something useful  
- where that time in software came from, IMO, is simply that typing characters on a keyboard was slow, so you needed more engineers who can type and think on one project  
- the more elements in a system, the higher the need for synchronization and verification of efforts (well, everyone types at different speeds ‚Äî an exaggerated way to put it)  
- introduce a sync element ‚Äî manager/lead  
- the number of sync elements grows like crazy ‚Äî you get processes/responsibility (a ‚Äúreduction/folding‚Äù function)  
- and that‚Äôs basically our whole industry today  

One of the ‚Äúinnovations‚Äù AI brings is cutting time on the very first point ‚Äî coding. And even if, according to many, it was never really the bottleneck, it still held up the headcount in the industry. Now imagine it‚Äôs not a question anymore. Then the number of people will shrink hard. And with it all the layers above (they‚Äôll get hit even more, because they often didn‚Äôt have a clue what the hell is even going on in the code). PMs, product folks, and the rest. Because the people who‚Äôll be able to run experiments will be the ones who simply hold responsibility ‚Äî and there were always few of those (few people like risk).

There are tons of examples of this kind of compression:
- the early-20th-century assembly line  
- industrialization (people leaving the fields)  
- etc  

And there‚Äôs a second fundamental shift AI brings: the ability to work with non-deterministic user input. This will seriously change UI and then UX. More on that later.

By the way  
not a bad vacancy,  
pretty fresh. I remember even a year ago there were ones like that there.  
And their (DeepMind‚Äôs) cofounder says the following pretty confidently (claims it‚Äôs been his view since 2009, like):
- in 2028 we‚Äôre in for minimal AGI, the kind that can do all tasks including cognitive ones, except the ones requiring extra abilities (like tasks for geniuses and so on, hard to say what he even means here, but that‚Äôs how he defined it)
- and then in ~5 years (he wrote like he‚Äôd be surprised if it takes a year, and if it takes 10 he‚Äôd also be surprised) there‚Äôll be full AGI, like any task a human solves can be solved  
Link to the tweet  
Link to his PhD thesis

Some observations. In my feel, automating coding will lead to an interesting effect:
1/ the engineer profession will get closer to the scientist profession ‚Äî meaning where ideas and understanding are pricier than applied skills (that‚Äôs actually how it was way back in the 70s‚Äì80s)
2/ the amount of trash software will be huge, but nobody will need it. This is that thing where every product person or mediocre engineer rushes to build ‚Äúproducts.‚Äù Yeah, there‚Äôll be more of them. But there‚Äôll be a TikTok effect: when the choice is that huge, people will pick the best. And the best requires a higher level of approach.
3/ overall nothing will change, I think. Yeah the feedback loop will get faster, yeah iterations will get cheaper, but that‚Äôs all on top of ‚Äúso what the hell are we even supposed to do‚Äù

Way more interesting is to watch whether progress shifts in theoretical digging (research automation). Because so far it‚Äôs not that cool there. But there are movements.

Intern search post (you can be with almost no experience, students and so on). Repost if you know where to, or you‚Äôve got contacts or followers.

What we‚Äôd like from a candidate:

What we offer:

Form to fill out if you‚Äôre interested is here

Long story short, I‚Äôve been meaning to write you a guide for your project for a while. If you suddenly decided to build a startup, then:
- either you‚Äôre looking for a way to build distribution almost for free
- or you‚Äôve found a way to chop hundreds of percent in margin
Everything else imo is a weird idea. Right now it‚Äôs super fashionable to ride the AI wave and build new tools (plug in a task and solve it with AI). And off everyone goes making primitive ideas, but since you can automate them that‚Äôs already a ‚Äúworthy project.‚Äù Remember the dot-com bubble (everyone started making websites). Now it‚Äôs about the same. Besides the obvious ‚Äúthis doesn‚Äôt need to be automated,‚Äù most of it doesn‚Äôt scale and doesn‚Äôt make money even if you fully meet all the conditions.
That‚Äôs exactly why I‚Äôm very skeptical about the run rate metric (they love calling it ARR now, even though that‚Äôs a mistake). The fact you can generate big revenue at huge costs only shows the market is willing to look at AI craft projects, but it says nothing about whether anyone will need this long-term.
